This place is great for casual dining of Taiwanese food here in DTLA. I was able to get a table reservation for 20 which is nice but it's also a casual order and dine in place.

We had a prix fixe menu that had many of the menu items. The beef rolls, popcorn fried chicken,vegan mapotofu, three cup chicken and fried tofu & mushrooms were excellent.  The hakka mochi and smashed cucumbers were delicious and refreshing. Overall the food was great.

The staff was very attentive and nice. They came over several times to check in on us and see if we needed anything. The decor and atmosphere is cool and a modern. Lots of spacing for individuals to sit at and eat and it's fairly well lit.

reviews.raw_text:
On approach, there was a small line of people waiting to order. I was looking forward to the Dan Dan Noodles, so I join the queue while checking the menu. A helpful staff took my order and showed me to my table.

The noodles definitely lived upto expectations. The softly cooked noodles were complemented by peanut sauce, thin strips of refreshing cucumber, coriander and sesame seeds - so smooth and creamy. The Forbidden Rice Pudding was a satisfying combination of black sticky rice, chewy taro and sweet potato balls and coconut milk.

Service was a little patchy overall except when the original server who took my order passed by - he was attentive and on point. The place was bustling from the weekend lunch crowd, clearly a popular choice for many. I'm sure this isn't my last visit to them - next time I'll try out the other offerings on the diverse menu.

reviews.raw_text:
It was my first time at Pine & Crane, and it immediately felt like a place I‚Äôd come back to. The food was fresh and amazing but somehow still new and unlike the common Chinese food I've had at other restaurants. (Get the Thousand Layer Pancake!). The atmosphere was also incredibly quiet and weirdly felt like we were in a garden. The easygoing vibe made it a comfortable spot to settle in and enjoy a meal.

What really stuck with me though, was the service -- specifically Benny at the cashier stand. He was warm, patient, and genuinely helpful with menu suggestions, making the whole process feel welcoming rather than rushed. The food and atmosphere were already great, but Benny‚Äôs service and knowledge is what turned a good first visit into something worth telling friends about.

Delightful! Tastes like elevated home cooking - the service and atmosphere reflects that coziness. Of the fried rice cakes, bean curds, sticky rice, wontons, beef noodles, classic shaved ice, and hakka mochi I‚Äôve tried here, I‚Äôd get the sticky rice, beef noodles, and hakka mochi again - I‚Äôm already craving them and saving this spot for the next time I‚Äôm in LA. The noodles were cooked to perfection, and the beef was pull-apart tender. The other items were good to try once- minus the bean curd, which wasn‚Äôt to my taste- but I wasn‚Äôt obsessed as I was with the three I highlighted.

Overall, their food features unique flavor combinations that work - and multiple sources including my taste buds say the soup dishes never miss.

The line gets long, but the mini market at the front provides plenty of visual delights to entertain yourself while you wait. Soak up the atmosphere, king!

reviews.raw_text:
At this restaurant, you place your order at the counter and pay in advance, so it‚Äôs a good idea to have an idea of what you‚Äôd like before stepping up to order. The interior is fairly spacious with a nice sense of openness, making it comfortable to dine in without feeling crowded. Drinks such as water are self-serve, which adds to the casual atmosphere. Compared to a full-service restaurant, it feels much more approachable and easy to visit, even for someone dining alone.

The food itself was excellent flavorful, well-prepared, and served in portions that felt just right, not overly large. Since the cuisine is Chinese, it‚Äôs perfect for sharing with friends or family, allowing everyone to enjoy a variety of dishes together. During my visit, I tried several items including the mapo tofu, boiled dumplings, mixed noodles, and fried chicken. Every dish was delicious, full of flavor, and very satisfying.

There were also several types of rice to choose from, which made the meal feel customizable to personal taste. Although I wasn‚Äôt able to try dessert this time, the options looked very tempting, and I would love to save room for one on my next visit. The pricing felt quite reasonable given the quality and variety, making it a place I could easily see myself coming back to whenever I‚Äôm craving good Chinese food.

We are always pleased with how quickly the food comes out after placing our orders & it‚Äôs always delicious. Some of our favorites are the Beef Roll, Panfried Pork Buns, Three Cup Chicken, and Taiwanese Popcorn Chicken.  It‚Äôs really good to order several dishes & share, and the restaurant encourages this by having small plates available to use. We leave happy and full every time.
reviews.parking: Because this is in Downtown LA.,parking can be tricky. There may be some open spaces close by but paid parking options might also have to be considered. We‚Äôve actually gotten lucky each time we‚Äôve visited and found free street parking. This may be due to the days or times we visited (we‚Äôre not from LA so not clear on all of the parking options).

reviews.raw_text:
Pine & Crane has a stylish, modern vibe and a menu that puts a fresh spin on classic Taiwanese and Chinese dishes. The ingredients taste fresh, and the presentation is solid. I really enjoyed the Dan Dan noodles and the Mapo Tofu ‚Äîboth had great texture and flavor.

That said, the experience didn‚Äôt totally live up to the hype. The service was friendly but slow, and a couple of dishes, like the hot and sour soup and beef noodle soup lacked the boldness and heat I expected. Portion sizes felt a bit small for the price, especially given the more casual, order-at-the-counter setup.

Overall, it‚Äôs a decent spot if you‚Äôre in the mood for something light and modern, but it didn‚Äôt quite wow me. Worth trying once, but not sure I‚Äôd rush back.

It was my first time visit this restaurant in the morning. I ordered pan fried pork buns, you tiao, iced sweetened soy milk, and a fan tuan to go. I highly recommend fan tuan because the taste is actually the same in Taiwan. For pork buns, not much flavorful. The soy milk is pretty good actually!

I will come by lunch or dinner time to try different menus!

*update on 5/6
Went back to try the lunch menu. Ordered a won ton soup and a beef noodle soup. I believe won ton soup with sea weed and some pepper would be better! As for the beef noodle soup, three huge beaf with great soup, better have the noodles with the soup to get more flavor!

Willing to try the other dishes on the menu.

I‚Äôve been to this spot about three times and all times it‚Äôs been a great spot to be satisfied for lunch/dinner.

My most recent order I got their taro milk tea boba with egg pudding and red bean.  It was a solid drink and very filling.

I‚Äôve had their Taiwanese sausage to mix with their minced pork on rice. The sausage  was excellent but I wasn‚Äôt a fan of the minced pork.  The beef roll was a solid meal also with great flavors. The Taiwanese popcorn chicken was my favorite appetizer and it was cooked/seasoned perfectly.

Their pork belly clamshell bun was also a great appetizer to have.  Their Dan dan noodles was really delicious too along with their hot & sour soup. As for dessert I think the forbidden rice pudding was way better than the grass jelly dessert. The forbidden rice pudding is my favorite meal there.

I‚Äôd definitely come back here again to try their other menu items. Parking can be tricky but worth the trip.

reviews.raw_text:
This Taiwanese restaurant near the Lakers' home arena is reasonably priced. It's about a 10-15 minute walk from the arena, and there are parking spaces along the street; you might find a spot if you're lucky.

We arrived around 2 PM, and there was a slight queue. After ordering, you find a seat yourself. This time, the two of us ordered rice cake, braised pork rice, hot and sour soup, and wonton soup. To be honest, it's a bit different from the food I've had in Taiwan, but the portions are really large. Someone with a small appetite like me should probably just order a rice cake and a bowl of soup.

The staff were very friendly. The downside is that there aren't many restrooms, so if it's crowded, the wait can be quite long.

reviews.raw_text:
Came here on a Monday around lunchtime, probably around 1pm. The place was busy with a 6 person lineup ahead of us. We ordered and found some nice seats. The vibe is nice and the process was easy.

We ordered the pork belly bun, dan dan noodles, beef roll and popcorn chicken‚Äî oh and some canned sake! The food came out at a good pace and everything was flavorful. Food is pretty good but overrated and overhyped in my opinion.  I can list at least 5 Taiwanese restaurants in SGV that are much better and you no need to wait for half an hour for a table.  Also, instead of taking reservation or using YELP to reserve a place in line, like other popular restaurants, it makes you stand in a line.  When the line overflowed and you had to wait outside the restaurant, it was a mess, people would cut in front of you, or one person would have 10 additional persons joining him all of a sudden.  I guess if you are in DTLA and have to have a Taiwanese food fix, this would do the job.

When the line overflowed and you had to wait outside the restaurant, it was a mess, people would cut in front of you, or one person would have 10 additional persons joining him all of a sudden.  I guess if you are in DTLA and have to have a Taiwanese food fix, this would do the job.

I needed to let everyone know about the staff of this establishment. They are INCREDIBLE! I have never been to a restaurant where the entire staff is so thoughtful, considerate and planning ahead. I‚Äôm blown away!

The food is amazing too, but the star of the show has to be the staff!

We had multiple staff members helping us during our lunch. I accidentally spilled some beer, someone came up immediately to give us a hand. My cousin needed a bottle opening for her Coke, someone came by with one without us even asking. They continuously bussed the table as we dined. They also offered utensils and to-go boxes even though there is an area where all of that is available for the patrons.
I cannot believe how incredibly thoughtful they are all especially how busy they always are as well.
They need to write a book on customer experience and how to elevate it to their level. Honestly, I‚Äôd come back not only for the food but to experience the whole thing again. You usually see this kind of service only being offered at super fancy restaurants which is always puzzling to me.
I do hope this means the staff isn‚Äôt only well trained but paid very well, too!

reviews.raw_text:
Taiwanese restaurant that has traditional Taiwanese breakfast food.
----------
Sweet Soy Milk
Grade: A
Rich and thick unlike the premade box and canned soy milk you can get in America. Basically as fresh as it gets.
----------
Fan Tuan
Grade: B-
Breakfast Rice "burrito". Rice has nice texture and they put a whole egg in but I feel like the flavors could've been a bit more balanced between the salty and sour and the wet and dry.
-----------
Dan Bing
Grade: B
Savory egg pancake with a savory peanut sauce. Pancake is really soft and the sauce is very authentic to the one they have in Taiwan. There is corn inside which I'm not totally accustomed to
----------
Savory Soy Milk
Grade: B-
A dish pretty unique to Taiwan as they use vinegar or another acid to curdle the soy milk. Almost tastes like little crushed tofu soup. Traditionally served with yiu tiao (crueller or Chinese donut) and then garnished with some pickled vegetables, fresh herbs, and hot oil. Pretty authentic but is a bit lighter on flavor.
----------
Yiu Tiao (fried crueller or Chinese donut)
Grade: C
Pretty standard but was a bit more on the hard crunchy side than the flaky crispy side. Different places make them differently and I prefer the lighter airier one.

reviews.raw_text:
We came on a Friday night at 8:30 but prior to driving to the restaurant, we called and asked about the wait. The attendant said 10 minutes. When we got there, we waited 45 minutes before we were seated at a table. You had to stand outside, wait to get your order taken, receive a number then wait outside again to get seated. Once we sat down, food came fairly quick (10 minutes). We also ordered dessert, which is a different card that they pick up to indicate you had dessert. We were done eating and waited for that dessert for over 20 minutes. The guy who took the card probably forgot about it, another person asked what else we were waiting for and we told him we were still waiting for dessert. Neither of them brought it. They asked again what we were waiting for and finally bright it out after waiting another 10 minutes. The shrimp wonton barely had flavor, the pork bun was average, the beef roll was flavorless and the Hakka mochi was underwhelming. I will never be back.

The restaurant has high ceilings and has open space concepts, allowing the outside breeze to flow freely through the restaurant. Sadly, the walk along the street leading to this restaurant was overwhelmed with urine smell.

I came to this place at around 2:00pm with some friends. The setup is very smart, you first place your order and pay for your food, then you grab a number and sit on a table and wait for them to deliver your order to your table. Shoutout to Ash, one of the nicest servers ever. The food itself is delicious and approachable. It feels like genuine Taiwanese food that you could get at a nice restaurant in SGV. The Shrimp Wontons were specially tasty and I even enjoyed my Minced Pork On Rice a lot. Highly recommended to check this place out if you're in the area. The ambiance is nice, since it has an open layout and it's quite refreshing (behind the restaurant, there's a really nice park with a sculpture in the shape of a chicken bone, lol. Go and see for yourself so you know what I mean).

reviews.raw_text:
This spot quickly got on my "must have" visits for DTLA. The choices are plentiful and the option to make dishes vegetarian or vegan is a plus. I had the beef bone broth noodles and the seasonal veggies, which today were yo choy (in the same family as bok choy).  The beef shank was fall off the bone tender, the broth was layered and flavorful, and the noodles had a good balance of chew and pull. The sesame oil saut√©ed yo choy had a flavor more mild than bok choy, but a great heft due to ratio of leaf to stem and the weight the woodsy stems.

I had the Chrysanthemum tea service, I highly enjoyed and recommend it. The bouquet/smell was 100% mum smell, but the slightly astringent bite mellowed at the end for a pleasant drink. Pine and Crane also has complimentary sparkling water on tap (!) that was a happy find.

reviews.raw_text:
We arrived at peak dinner rush, when the place looked packed and were the pioneers of the out-the-door line. They opened the door after we went out and it stayed open while we were there to accommodate the out-the-door line.
Honestly, I was a bit nervous about the wait considering how packed it was, but they ha a sign that explained that after the you order you'll get a number and a member of the staff will help you get seated and that normally there's close to no wait. That turned out to be true! By the time we ordered our food, our group of 4 was immediately seated.

Now, the service was warm and attentive, the concept itself is super cool, the food was delicious and above all else this is amazing value for the money.

I'd argue that this is a can't miss spot in DT of you're around for longer than a day or two. I couldn't believe the price tag considering delicious the food was and how well run the establishment is.

Kudos to them and we'd be back on our next visit.

In all fairness, I attended a private event with buffet style food and drinks, so I will need to come back to try the menu fare. My favorites from the buffet style group meal was definitely the popcorn chicken. They offered Mabo Tofu, dumplings, bok choy, etc. Good, but nothing special.  Again, I'll come back and try the menu items.

I loved the 2 pre-made cocktails that they mass produced to serve the wedding rehearsal guests that were in their 2 big plastic dispensers. I was skeptical at first, but they were tasty and refreshing.

I loved the open air atmosphere and high ceilings. It's definitely a trendy Taiwanese eatery and water hole.

reviews.raw_text:
My friend and I were starving after a day pool party and wanted something other than burgers or wings, so wandered over. I've heard great things about Pine & Crane for years so it was cute to finally try it! You don't get seated until after you make your orders, but once we sorted ourselves together they were quick to serve us. My friend ordered shellfish and they were AMAZING and on top of it regarding allergy and took cross contamination very seriously too! The kitchen, front of house and server were all very sharp and clear communicators and knew precisely what was in the food or how to take care of their guests. I also loved the concept and it reminded me so much of Hawai'i and made me miss home. I love this place and it's definitely on my shortlist for a quick bite both small and filling. I was a little sad that the pork buns were sold out, but it was a Saturday night at 8:30pm - it must have been really good. Big ups to Jonathan and Liz, appreciate you both for being so sweet, professional, patient and kind! Rockstars!

reviews.raw_text: Pine and Crane is one of the places I would recommend to any of my friends for casual dinner in DTLA, but it is sad to share that I had an unpleasant experience today. The female Asian server today was somewhat in a hurry, and as we were already getting ready to leave (we were putting the left-over boxes in the bag), she rushed into cleaning our table and dropped silverwares on us, without proper apologies. My friend was so shocked. We left after 30 seconds she picked up all the plates from our table, I looked around and there were so many empty tables. I don‚Äôt know how much difference it could have made as she could have cleaned after 30 seconds, and I don‚Äôt know why she was so eager to clean it and couldn‚Äôt wait for that 30 seconds. Maybe this could be improved as the restaurant already offers lots of self-service.

reviews.raw_text:
You will love everything about Pine & Crane. It is Thai food at its best and they have everything.

All of the food is excellent. All their ingredients are Fresh. The place is very clean and the service is fast and really nice. You order at the counter and pick up. We love eating here. There is great outdoor seating and you won't have all the Downtown LA traffic noise. It is just nice and relaxing.

We love all their dumplings.   Their beef  noodle dish is hard to say no to and they give you a goodly amount.  They also have the best rice dishes with pretty much whatever you want in it.  Their soups are fresh and just so good.

You can eat there, do take away, pick up and eat in your car or a nearby park (be careful with that) and I bet they deliver.

Have a wonderful time.

The ambience is great! Very nice and homey spot. The staff was very kind too. We ordered a bit of everything.

Pros:
Prices are very good for all the dishes. Nothing was over 15 dollars on the menu. The shrimp wontons and pan fried pork buns were the best items with the most flavor. The beef roll was huge in size. Great for people that enjoy cucumber and thicker slices of the meat. The bean curd salad had a nice bite and flavor to it. They also have sparkling water on tap!

Cons:
Parking is bad. Getting street parking is like winning the lottery.  The other option is to pay for parking which can range between 10-30 dollars. The dan dan noodles and sha gua mian did not meet our expectations. The noodles seemed a bit overcooked and a sauce/acid could have given the dish more of a balance in flavor.

Our table marker was taken off the table a little early and that's when we saw on the receipt that a missing item was added incorrectly. Our server fixed it promptly so that was great.

reviews.raw_text:
Came here for dinner on a Sunday evening with a group of 4, and we loved it! It‚Äôs a fairly casual establishment where you order at the front, take a table number, and then find an open table to sit at. It was fairly busy, but we had no trouble finding a table since they have a good amount of seating available. The food comes out lightning quick, with dishes being brought out as they are ready rather than all coming out together. All the food was excellent, with a great combination of flavors and textures in each dish. The popcorn chicken and crispy rice cakes & mushrooms were delightfully crispy, and the braised beef in the beef noodle soup was melt in your mouth tender. The beef roll and pan fried pork buns were some of my favorites, and the dan dan noodles were also excellent. I highly recommend going with a group so that you can try a variety of different dishes - it‚Äôs so hard to pick just one! Will definitely try to make it back here again next time I‚Äôm downtown.

reviews.raw_text:
Now this is some legit Taiwanese food! Opened late for delivery which allowed my friend and I to enjoy one of the best Valentine's Day dinners ever.

We ordered a completely plant-based menu and everything we had was delicious. All vegetarian and vegan friendly items are clearly marked on their menu.

Started with the Rice Cakes & Mushrooms appetizer which are an absolute must- everything was fried perfectly and seasoned with salt, pepper, and basil. I bet if these were eaten fresh, they would have been even better.

Next, we had their Bok Choy Dumplings which were four large, pan-fried pieces of goodness that came with a fire dipping sauce. They seriously have the texture of their dumplings down perfectly.

Finally, the Dan Dan Noodles completed the meal - wheat noodles covered in a seasoned sesame based dressing with fresh cucumbers and peanuts. The dish is simple but it was one of the best DDN I've had in a while.

I look forward to checking out the actual restaurant in the future because the delivery was amazing. I can only imagine how even better it is when made fresh with great ambiance and service.

Have always liked Pine & Crane food. High quality but traditional Taiwanese breakfast and lunch/dinner. Pricier than SGV restaurants sure but really the best quality you can get in DTLA and anywhere west of it, short of Din Tai Fung. It‚Äôs a cool modern spot with a big patio and plenty of seating in the outskirts of DTLA. Nice service and a versatile space. Great place for a work lunch or just to camp out a bit to read and do some work. Get an iced green tea, cold brew coffee or maybe an adult beverage from their assortment of Asian whiskeys and bourbons. Highly recommended!

Started in Silver Lake Pine & Crane is a fast-casual Taiwanese Restaurant now located in shiny South Park DTLA digs, complete with an outdoor patio and friendly staff to go with a polished seating area inside.

Open for breakfast, lunch and dinner with a focus on ingredients, former Chinatown pop-up Today Starts Here contributing ideas not found at the original, it is on entry that guests will find counter-style service such that orders bought and paid for are delivered to tables in less than fifteen minutes.

Part ‚ÄúComfort Food‚Äù and part Street, juicy Pork Buns a bit doughy but perfectly seared on the bottom, Pine & Crane‚Äôs Fried Peanut Salad should not be overlooked by fans or novices as each bite delivers an array of Herbs and subtle spiciness.

More than generous in terms of price and portion, fried Rice Cakes & Mushrooms lighter than expected while the Beef Roll finds tender meat kissed with Hoisin inside a flaky Scallion Pancake, additional highlights include Shrimp Wontons bathed in vibrant Broth and Sticky Rice with tons of umami.

Open 8am to 10pm daily, Sea Salt Cream Cold Brew a good choice anytime, authenticity continues through Dessert where Red Bean, Taro, Sweet Potato and Grass Jelly can be found amidst a backdrop of everything from Shaved Ice to Rice Pudding.
